    Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS)-Responsive Prodrugs, Probes, and Theranostic Prodrugs: Applications in the ROS-Related Diseases

    • Pengfei Wang
      Pengfei Wang
      Jiangsu Key Laboratory of Drug Design and Optimization, and Department of Chemistry, China Pharmaceutical University, Nanjing 211198, China

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    Elevated levels of reactive oxygen species (ROS) have commonly been implicated in a variety of diseases, including cancer, inflammation, and neurodegenerative diseases. In light of significant differences in ROS levels between the nonpathogenic and pathological tissues, an increasing number of ROS-responsive prodrugs, probes, and theranostic prodrugs have been developed for the targeted treatment and precise diagnosis of ROS-related diseases. This review will summarize and provide insight into recent advances in ROS-responsive prodrugs, fluorescent probes, and theranostic prodrugs, with applications to different ROS-related diseases and various subcellular organelle-targetable and disease-targetable features. The ROS-responsive moieties, the self-immolative linkers, and the typical activation mechanism for the ROS-responsive release are also summarized and discussed.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are a series of chemically reactive oxygen-containing molecules, such as hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), superoxide (O2â), superoxide radical anion (O2Ìâ¢â), and hydroxyl radical (Â·OH), which play an indispensable physiological role in cell signal transduction, acting as secondary messengers.(1â4) ROS homeostasis is critical for maintaining normal cell metabolism, proliferation, and differentiation.(5,6) However, abnormally elevated ROS levels in cells may cause oxidative stress due to their high chemical reactivity, which can lead to cellular dysfunction, induce pathological changes,(7) and contribute to the progression of diseases, such as cancer,(8,9) inflammation,(10) and neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimerâs disease (AD) and Parkinsonâs disease (PD).(11â13)
    Cellular ROS production primarily occurs in the mitochondria.(14) Both NADH ubiquitin reductase (complex I) and ubiquitin cytochrome c reductase (complex III) of the mitochondrial electron transport chain are involved in the univalent reduction of O2 to O2Ìâ¢â.(15) Among them, mitochondrial proteins such as E2 subunits of pyruvate dehydrogenase are the main targets of oxidative stress.(16) Previous studies have demonstrated that arsenic trioxide, an approved drug for the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia, can elevate the production of H2O2 in mitochondria and produce hydroxyl radicals through the Fenton reaction, leading to oxidative damage of pyruvate dehydrogenase.(17,18) The disruption of such mitochondrial enzyme activities by arsenic trioxide will reduce the ability of cancer cells to meet energy requirements, thus causing cancer cell death.(17,18) Additionally, enzymes such as NADPH oxidases (NOXs), nitric oxide synthase, and xanthine oxidase will also contribute to the generation of ROS with superoxide and hydrogen peroxide as byproducts of their catalytic processes.(19,20) The NOXs family of enzymes are composed of a flavoprotein, cytochrome b, and regulatory subunits specific to the family member and are considered to be crucial for ROS production. When activated, NOXs assemble in the cell membrane and reduce oxygen to superoxide.(19,20) Physiologically, the endogenous ROS levels are stably maintained at a low level of approximately 20 Ã 10â3 Î¼M in normal cells owing to the cellular redox homeostasis.(21) However, it has been suggested that ROS levels in the pathological tissue of certain ROS-related diseases, such as cancer and inflammation, could reach significantly higher concentrations of up to 100 Î¼M.(11) Those diseased cells could adapt to significantly increased levels of ROS.(22,23) Thus, ROS have been selected as a starting point or target for diagnosis and therapy of various ROS-related diseases.(24,25) In light of the significant differences in ROS levels between nonpathogenic and pathological tissues, an increasing number of ROS-responsive prodrugs, probes, and theranostic prodrugs have been developed for the targeted treatment and precise diagnosis of the ROS-related diseases.
    Of the endogenous ROS, H2O2 has been regarded as the most crucial member with a relatively weaker reactivity in the cells and relatively higher concentrations compared to other ROS.(26) The mitochondrion is the primary site of H2O2 production, and the cell respiratory rate determines the level of H2O2 in the cytoplasm and other intracellular compartments.(27,28) H2O2 plays a variety of physiological functions in vivo, including immune response,(29) cell signaling,(30) and regulation of oxidative stress.(31) In particular, the responses of cell signaling to H2O2 are dose-dependent and cell-type-specific.(32) An increase in H2O2 concentration may lead to oxidative cell damage through the loss of protein function.(33) The determination of H2O2 levels in living cells is a crucial factor in understanding the mechanism of disease development and pharmacodynamics; the distribution of H2O2 in living cells may differ in subcellular organelles. In this case, fluorescent probes can make a specific and sensitive response to changes in H2O2 concentrations in cells, enabling the monitoring and detection of H2O2 levels within living cells and even in subcellular organelles, thus providing useful tools for exploring the process of drug action, the function of H2O2 in living cells, and clinical physiological diagnosis.(34,35)
    In recent decades, significant progress in ROS-responsive prodrugs, probes, and theranostic prodrugs has occurred. This review will summarize and provide insight into recent advances in ROS-responsive prodrugs, fluorescent probes, and theranostic prodrugs, in particular their application to different ROS-related diseases and various subcellular organelle-targetable and disease-targetable features. The ROS-responsive prodrugs have been classified according to the ROS-responsive moieties, such as the typical arylboronates, thiazolidinone, and selenium- or sulfur-containing classes. Additionally, the self-immolative linkers and typical activation mechanisms related to the ROS-responsive release will also be summarized and discussed.

    2. Activation Mechanisms of the ROS-Responsive Prodrugs

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Boronates, including boronate esters and boronic acids, are important chemical functional groups responsive to ROS in cells.(36â39) Structurally, the boron atom in boronates contains an empty p-orbital that is susceptible to attack by nucleophiles such as H2O2, a major member of the ROS family. In the case of phenylboronate, a subsequent BaeyerâVilliger oxidation-like rearrangement, followed by hydrolysis, will lead to the formation of a phenolic hydroxyl group, which may initiate the bond breaking of a typical cleavable linker and subsequent release of an active parent drug under physiological conditions.(40) Thus, phenylboronate is the most common âROS trigger groupâ to be introduced in a ROS-responsive prodrug.(41) As illustrated in Figure 1, H2O2 or its dissociated anionic form is prone to attacking the electrophilic boron center of the arylboronate-containing prodrug (1a) to form a tetrahedral boronate intermediate (1b). Then, the phenyl group migrates from the boron (B) atom to the adjacent oxygen (O) atom through a 1,2-rearrangement reaction to give the borate (1c). Compared with the structure of 1a, 1c has an oxygen atom inserted within the original carbonâboron bond. Subsequently, the borate 1c is easily hydrolyzed under physiological conditions, converting into a boric acid/ester and the corresponding phenolic intermediate 1d. Generally, the rate of reaction between H2O2 and the boronate moiety as in 1a to form 1d is quite fast, with most of prodrug 1a completely converted to 1d in 15 min.(42,43) Following a 1,6-elimination reaction, the methylphenyloxy linker in 1d is spontaneously cleaved, leading to the release of the parent drug (1e) and para-benzoquinone methide (p-QM) (1f). The latter will then convert into 1g or 1h upon reaction with H2O or glutathione (GSH), respectively, in cells. The final 1,6-elimination step is considered to be the rate-limiting step of the ROS-responsive drug release.(43)
    Structurally, a ROS-responsive prodrug should include two independent functional domains, a ROS acceptor (trigger) and a pharmacodynamic agent (effector), which are usually connected by a self-cleavable âlinker systemâ (linker).(44) As shown in Figure 2, we have summarized various linking strategies for designing the arylboronate-containing ROS-responsive prodrugs based on parent drugs with different functional groups. In the case of parent drugs with an aromatic hydroxyl group, their corresponding prodrugs could be designed by using an ether-type cleavable linker (type A) or a carbonate ester-type cleavable linker (type B) or by replacing the hydroxyl with its boronate precursor, directly linked to the parent scaffold via a carbonâboron bond (type C). It is worth noting that the chemical types of linkers affect the rates of self-cleavage and drug release. Jourden et al. investigated different self-immolative linkers (types AâC) on the releasing rates of the parent drug; the results suggested that the carbonate ester-type cleavable linkage (type B) was the most efficient and fastest linkage for drug release. It can be postulated that this is because the hydrolysis process of boronate ester and the linker cleaving process could be accelerated by the thermodynamics of CO2 release.(45) Prodrugs with the self-immolative ether linker (type A) can release parent drugs upon ROS-responsive oxidation and hydrolysis, followed by the 1,6-elimination cleavage. Prodrugs without a self-immolative linker, as in type C, possessed a similar boronate moiety to that in type A. The drug-releasing rate of type C was found to be approximately 2 orders of magnitude slower than that of type A or type B, indicating that self-immolative linkers were more advantageous for converting prodrugs into the active parent drugs upon ROS stimulation.(45)
    For parent drugs containing the functional group of either hydroxamic acid or amine, similar self-immolative linkers, shown as type D and type E in Figure 2, could be utilized to construct the ROS-responsive prodrugs.(44,45) Importantly, the carbamate self-immolative linker (type E) may still be the first choice for the development of prodrugs based on the structures with an amine group because carbamate is relatively chemically stable and the thermodynamic property of CO2 release is favorable for drug release.(46) As seen, self-immolative linkers are widely used and play critical roles in the design and development of the boronate-containing ROS-responsive prodrugs.
    Apart from the typical arylboronates, the heterocycle thiazolidinone could also be used as a âROS triggerâ group for designing prodrugs based on the parent drugs with a carboxyl pharmacophore (Figure 3).(47) The carbonyl group in prodrug (2a) is susceptible to attack by the nucleophilic H2O2 to form 2b. Subsequently, 2b converts rapidly into 2c, where the thiazolidinone moiety acts as a robust leaving group. The formed peroxy acid 2c is easily hydrolyzed under physiological pH conditions, leading to the release of the parent drug with a carboxyl pharmacophore (2e).(48)
    Recently, selenium and sulfur atoms have been utilized as âROS triggerâ groups in some types of ROS-responsive prodrugs as they are prone to be oxidated in the presence of high levels of ROS in cells. As shown in Figure 4, following a ROS-mediated oxidation reaction in cells, the selenium-containing prodrug 3a converted into 3b; the latter underwent a syn-elimination reaction to form a double bond between the C5 and C6 sites and gave 3c. The intermediate 3c was extremely unstable, undergoing a cheletropic/retro-DielsâAlder reaction to release parent drug CO spontaneously under very mild conditions (Figure 4).(49) This is an interesting prodrug strategy that uses an inter- and intramolecular DielsâAlder cycloaddition to trigger the release of CO caged in a cyclopentadienone moiety.(49) Additionally, sulfur-containing thioketal (TK) linkers are prone to be oxidized to sulfoxides or sulfones upon exposure to ROS through oxidation; the methylene sulfones may be rapidly cleaved by hydrolysis under physiological conditions to release active drugs, 4c (Figure 4).(50) Such sulfur-containing cleavable linkers have been commonly used in polymeric prodrugs. For example, polymeric prodrug 4a formed micelles by self-assembly in aqueous solutions. In cancer cells, the elevated levels of ROS initiated the oxidation reaction to give 4b and subsequent hydrolysis triggered the TK linker to break, leading to the selective release of the corresponding active drug 4c in cancer cells (Figure 4).(51,52)
    Aryl oxalate esters,(53) thioethers,(54) and tellurium(55) have also been reported as ROS-responsive moieties with similar release mechanisms to the above-mentioned moieties, thiazolidinone and thioketal. Additionally, polypeptide chains containing multiple proline, histidine, lysine, and arginine residues were found to be susceptible to oxidative cleavage.(56â58) Among them, a proline oligomer was commonly utilized as the ROS-responsive moiety in biomedical materials.(56,58) However, it has rarely been applied in the design of small-molecule ROS-responsive prodrugs. A summary of all the reported ROS-responsive structures is listed in Table 1, outlining the different types of ROS-responsive sites, moieties, and release mechanisms.
    Table 1. Brief Summary of the ROS-Responsive Structures

    3. ROS-Responsive Prodrugs

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    3.1. ROS-Responsive Anticancer Prodrugs

    Considering that cancer cells commonly exhibit significantly higher levels of ROS than normal cells, modification of anticancer agents into prodrugs by introducing ROS-responsive groups to mask the critical cytotoxic pharmacophore moiety is a promising strategy to improve the safety profiles of nonselective antitumor agents.(24)
    DNA interstrand cross-link (ICL)-inducing agents have been widely used in cancer chemotherapy, mediating their clinical outcomes through interruption of DNA replication and transcription.(59) However, these drugs usually incur severe side effects due to their poor selectivity to affect only cancer cells. In 2011, Peng et al. reported the H2O2-activated anticancer prodrugs 5 and 6 (Figure 5), based on the structures of nitrogen mustards.(60) The positive charge generated by the quaternary nitrogen in 5 and 6 significantly decreased the electron density of mustard nitrogens that induces chemical alkylation, thus masking the cytotoxicity of these compounds. In cancer cells, the reaction of phenylboronate or phenylboronic acid (trigger) with ROS led to a significant increase in cytotoxicity of nitrogen mustards (effector), while the prodrugs 5 and 6 showed a significantly reduced intrinsic toxicity. In cell-based assays, the cancer cells were usually treated with additional H2O2 to mimic the high oxidative stress level of tumor tissues. When the ratio of prodrug 5 or 6 to H2O2 was 2:1, the observed rate constant of induced ICL formation was 4.6 Ã 10â5 sâ1 or 4.7 Ã 10â5 sâ1, respectively. The cross-linking efficiency of 5 and 6 was 43%, which is comparable to that of nitrogen mustard alone (47% ICLs). The growth-inhibitory rates of 5 and 6 toward SR cells (leukemia cells), NCI-H460 (non-small-cell lung cancer cells), CAKI-1, and SN12C (renal cancer cells) at 10 Î¼M were 90%, 85%, 66%, and 57%, respectively. Under the same cell conditions, 5 and 6 did not cause apoptosis in normal lymphocytes, demonstrating good preliminary safety profiles in vitro.(60) In 2014, Peng et al. further investigated various electron-withdrawing linkers and identified an effective anticancer prodrug 7 with a carbamate linker (Figure 5).(61)In vitro cytotoxicity assays revealed that 7 possessed potent inhibitory activity toward a variety of cancer cell lines, including leukemia, lung cancer, breast cancer, and renal cancer, with GI50 values below 1 Î¼M.(61) Additionally, Peng et al. reported another neutral type of ROS-activated prodrug 8 (Figure 5).(62) Compared with the charged prodrugs 5 and 6, the neutral prodrug 8 was proposed to more easily penetrate cell membranes. In vitro cytotoxicity assays demonstrated that 8 induced 40â80% apoptosis in primary leukemic lymphocytes isolated from chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) patients. In comparison, 8 was less toxic to normal lymphocytes from healthy donors (less than 25% cell death).(62) These results suggested that ROS-responsive prodrugs could potentially be a useful strategy for reducing the side effects of the nitrogen mustard-type antitumor drugs.
    Camptothecin (CPT), a potent anticancer drug derived from natural products, may suppress DNA replication and RNA synthesis by directly binding to topoisomerase I (TopoI).(63â65) SN-38 (Figure 6), a derivative of CPT, has a pharmacophore predominantly composed of a phenolic hydroxyl group, which can be used as a starting point for designing prodrugs to be selectively activated by ROS, such as H2O2. SN-38 could be released at a concentration of H2O2 as low as 0.5 mM in a concentration-dependent manner.(66) Compared with SN-38, prodrug 9 (Figure 6) displayed comparable cytotoxic activity toward MCF-7 and U251 cells and enhanced activity toward HT-29 cells.(66) Further, 9 was evaluated in the xenograft model to assess its antitumor activity in vivo. Following a dose of 2.0 mg/kg (ip), prodrug 9 exhibited significant antitumor activity with a ratio of tumor volume in treated versus control mice (T/C ratio) of 28.1%, which is comparable to that achieved with irinotecan, a reference drug, at a dose of 15 mg/kg (T/C = 8.39%); notably, no obvious toxicity or any anaphylactic reactions were observed, suggesting an improved safety profile for 9in vivo.(66) Similarly, a new evodiamine prodrug 10 (Figure 6) was designed using an arylboronate functional group as the initiator (Figure 6).(67) Potentially, it may induce apoptosis of HCT116 colon cancer cells in a dose-dependent manner and arrest the growth of HCT116 cells in the G2 phase. The in vitro assessment of antitumor effects revealed that 10 had good antiproliferative activity toward HCT116, MCF-7, and A549 cancer cells with IC50 values ranging from 16 Î¼M to 37 Î¼M. Notably, the cytotoxic activity of 10 against HCT116 cells (IC50 = 16 Î¼M) was slightly more potent than the lead compound 3-fluoro-10-hydroxyevodiamine (IC50 = 27 Î¼M).(67)
    Histone deacetylase (HDAC) is a crucial enzyme in cellular regulation of the acetylation levels of histones and non-histones to affect the dense structure of chromatin to achieve epigenetic regulation. Abnormal overexpression of many HDAC isoforms was found to be related to cancer development. Thus, HDAC inhibitors (HDACi) could be developed for the treatment of cancer.(68) Hydroxamic acid derivatives are the most investigated chemotype for HDACi because the hydroxamic acid moiety is an excellent chelator for binding to the Zn2+ cation in the active site of HDACs. Vorinostat (SAHA) and belinostat, representative HDAC inhibitors, were used for the treatment of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL) and relapsed/refractory peripheral T-cell lymphoma (PTCL), respectively.(69) However, their poor selectivity to cancer cells resulted in a series of unwanted side effects. Vascular calcification was a common side effect of the hydroxamic acid-containing HDACi.(70) Additionally, the hydroxamic acid moiety was unstable in vivo, leading to a decrease in the therapeutic effects.(71,72) Although acyl and carbamate derivatives of hydroxamate-based HDACi were developed to improve the cell permeability, hydrolysis stability, and pharmacokinetic properties, these molecules still lacked the desired specificity for cancer cells.(73) Srivastava et al. capped the hydroxamic acid residue of SAHA with a ROS-responsive group, 4-hydroxymethylboronic pinacol ester, resulting in the SAHA prodrug 11a (Figure 6).(74) The carbonate ester-type prodrug 11a was found to be relatively stable in serum, while the phenylboronate may be reactive with H2O2 and rapidly generate the parent drug form with the hydroxamic acid. In vivo assays revealed that 11a showed an improved selectivity toward the ROS-sufficient cancer cells; the cytotoxicity of 11a toward the ROS-deficient HEK-293T normal cells was significantly reduced (EC50 > 1 Î¼M) when compared with SAHA (EC50 = 100 nM). Also, the lipophilicity of 11a increased dramatically with a cLogP value of 4.337, compared to the cLogP value for SAHA of 0.989. The cellular drug uptake of 11a was greatly accelerated, presumably due to increased lipophilicity in a multicellular tumor spheroid model.(74) Compared with SAHA, 11a was more efficient in reducing tumor spheroids size; 11a reduced tumor volume by 80%, while SAHA only reduced tumor volume by 50%.(74) Prodrug 11b, structurally similar to 11a, could be activated upon exposure to cellular H2O2, and consequently, the active HDACi released intracellularly then led to the suppression of viable acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells.(75) Prodrug 11b was also used in combination with conventional chemotherapy drugs, such as cytarabine, and other âtargetedâ anti-AML drugs to improve anticancer efficacy.(75) The same design strategy was employed to produce the belinostat prodrug 12 (Figure 6).(76) Wang et al. developed a ROS-responsive prodrug with therapeutic potential for the treatment of solid tumors, such as metastatic breast cancer, by introducing a phenylboronate moiety into the hydroxamic acid pharmacophore of belinostat. In vitro assays showed that 12 was active toward human breast adenocarcinoma MCF-7 cells with an IC50 value of 1.46 Î¼M. Although it was less potent than belinostat (IC50 = 0.096 Î¼M), no obvious cytotoxicity was observed for 12 toward normal mammary epithelial MCF-10A cells even at a relatively high concentration of 10 Î¼M. Importantly, prodrug 12 showed 85.4% inhibition of tumor growth (TGI) in an MCF-7 tumor xenograft model, which was more efficacious than belinostat in vivo (TGI = 77.7%). This may be attributed to the superior bioavailability of 12 within ROS-elevated tumor tissues; the drug concentration in tumor tissue in the 12-treated group was found to be more than 2-fold higher than in the belinostat-treated group.(76)
    Gemcitabine (GEM), a first-line drug for treating pancreatic cancer, was the primary adjuvant chemotherapy after radical surgery for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC).(77) However, its clinical application was limited due to severe side effects, such as myelosuppression. To improve the safety profile, a novel type of boronate clathrate prodrug, 13, was designed (Figure 6).(78) Prodrug 13 was found to be selectively activated by high levels of ROS in cancer cells, releasing GEM to induce the antitumor effects. Prodrug 13 exhibited a comparable potency to that of GEM in an immunodeficient xenograft mouse model in vivo. Notably, owing to its selective activation in cancer cells, the myelosuppression side effect of GEM was significantly reduced when administered with prodrug 13in vivo.(78)
    Doxorubicin (DOX) is an effective and broad-spectrum antitumor drug; however, its therapeutic application is significantly limited due to severe cardiotoxicity. Prodrug 14 (Figure 6) was designed by branching the amino group of DOX with a ROS-responsive arylboronate-based self-immolative linker.(79) Prodrug 14 manifested potent in vitro cytotoxicity toward several cancer cells, which was comparable with DOX. Significantly, the IC50 for 14 against the pancreatic MiPaCa-2 cells was 0.3 Î¼M. Additionally, prodrug 14 was found to efficiently release DOX in tumor tissues on a MiaPaca-2 tumor model, inferring promising therapeutic outcomes of such ROS-responsive prodrugs in the treatment of pancreatic cancer.(79)
    5-Fluorouracil (5-FU) has been used alone or in combination with other chemotherapy drugs for the treatment of various solid tumors. As an antimetabolic agent, 5-FU also inhibits the growth of normal cells and causes significant side effects.(80) Xue et al. designed ROS-responsive prodrugs of 5-FU, such as 15 and 16 (Figure 6), by introducing a phenylboronate group to 5-FU to mask its cytotoxicity toward normal cells.(80) Upon exposure to H2O2, 5-FU was efficiently released from the boronate ester prodrug 15, while the boronic acid prodrug showed a much slower 5-FU release. In vitro assays showed that prodrug 15 manifested highly selective cytotoxicity toward a variety of cancer cells, with no obvious cytotoxicity observed for 15 in normal MEC1 cells even at the high concentration of 100 Î¼M.(80) The acute toxicity of prodrug 15 was tested in C57BL/6 male mice, with no death or any other abnormalities observed in the prodrug 15-treated group at a high dose of 100 mg/kg throughout a 2-week treatment. All mice died on the 12th day in the 5-FU-treated group at the same dose. The results indicate that prodrug 15 possessed a significantly superior safety profile than the parent 5-FU and may reduce the side effects experienced with 5-FU, such as myelosuppression, central neurotoxicity, and gastrointestinal toxicity.(80)
    Melatonin (MLT), a tryptophan-derived hormone, has been shown to inhibit the growth of several types of cancers both in vitro and in vivo, although its mode of action remains controversial.(81) Recently, Bedini et al. reported an MLT prodrug (17) (Figure 6) with a ROS-responsive phenylboronate trigger inserted at the nitrogen of the indole scaffold within MLT.(43) Prodrug 17 could be selectively activated under the high H2O2 concentrations in cancer cells, releasing both the MLT and cytotoxic p-QM intermediate to exert synergistic antitumor effects. When treated with 50 Î¼M 17, the cytotoxic activity was evident in Hela cells; in contrast, no obvious cell death was observed in normal cells, suggesting that prodrug 17 was preferentially bioactivated by the elevated levels of ROS in cancer cells.(43)
    Perturbation of redox homeostasis by further inducing ROS production or GSH depletion to push the ROS levels in cancer cells to exceed the âtoxicity thresholdâ has been a promising strategy for cancer therapy.(82,83) 5,8-Dihydroxy-1,4-naphthoquinone, also known as naphthazarin (Nap), is a naturally occurring anticancer agent. The cytotoxicity of Nap is due to the adjacent carbonyl and hydroxy moieties acting as potential Cu(II) ionophores.(84) Recently, Zhou et al. reported a ROS-responsive prodrug of Nap, PNap (18) (Figure 7), where the two hydroxy groups are masked with a phenylboronate ROS trigger.(84)
    In addition to small molecule-based prodrugs, the ROS-responsive prodrug approach was also applied to modify proteins for target cancer therapy. RNase is a protein drug that has entered clinical trials for cancer treatment; it is capable of cleaving RNA and inducing cytotoxicity in cancer cells.(85,86) Wang et al. introduced an arylboronate ROS-responsive trigger onto a critical lysine residue of RNase A, which was essential for its activity, thus generating a ROS-responsive RNase, RNase A-NBC (19) (Figure 8). This modification led to a temporary inactivation of RNase, with prodrug 19 becoming reactivated by high levels of ROS in cancer cells.(46,87) Consequently, prodrug 19 manifested cytotoxicity selective to cancer cells, such as B16F10, PC-3, HeLa, and MDA-MB-231 cancer cells, and the cytotoxicity to normal cells was significantly reduced, leading to a considerable increase in tolerated dosages of RNase A to generate improved therapeutic outcomes in clinical use.(46)
    Mokhir et al. reported a novel group of aminoferrocene-based prodrugs, for example, 20 shown in Figure 9, where the parent aminoferrocene moieties are caged by phenylboronate ester-type ROS triggers. Prodrug 20 may be activated upon exposure to high levels of ROS in cancer cells to form a quinone methide (p-QM) and the parent drug aminoferrocenes.(88) The former could inhibit the antioxidant system of cancer cells, while the latter could induce rapid ROS generation in cancer cells, thus producing anticancer effects through a synergistic manner. The mechanism of the ROS-responsive drug release for 20 was illustrated in Figure 9. Upon exposure to high levels of H2O2, the boronâcarbon bond of 20 was cleaved to form phenol (20a), which existed in equilibrium with phenolate (20b) (pKa â 9) in an aqueous solution. Compound 20b then experienced a spontaneous 1,6-elimination reaction to produce 20c and p-QM.(89) Intermediate 20c was unstable in aqueous solution, resulting in rapid hydrolysis, leading to the release of the N-alkylaminoferrocene 20e together with a molecule of CO2. Compound 20e can be further oxidized by O2 or H2O2 to form aminoferrocene cation (20f) and generate HOÂ· or O2â, which are more active ROS. In addition, 20f may decompose to release iron ions, which catalyze the generation of more toxic ROS from less reactive H2O2 or O2.(89) Moreover, p-QM consumes ROS scavengers such as GSH, resulting in the inhibition of the antioxidant system in cancer cells (Figure 9).(88,90) It has been suggested that these pathways explained the induced synergistic effects on cancer cell growth inhibition.
    Structural modifications on the aminoferrocene-based prodrugs were explored by the Mokhir group to improve selectivity and potency toward cancer cells and drug-like properties, such as cell membrane permeability and water solubility.(90â94) Benzylation of the amino group on the ferrocene scaffold resulted in a series of N-substituted prodrugs, as represented by 21 (Figure 10). Prodrug 21 was found to be more cytotoxic toward many cancer cells such as HL-60, RAJI, BL-2, JVM-2, and LNCap cells, in comparison to its amino counterpart (20, R = H).(90,91) For instance, 21 manifested an IC50 of approximately 11 Î¼M on the growth of HL-60 leukemia cells.(90,92) Substituents on the benzyl of 21 with electron-donating or -accepting moieties, such as fluoro, methoxy, and acetoxy functional groups, had little effect on its cytotoxicity. Ex vivo and in vivo safety profiles of prodrug 21 were evaluated using rat cut liver slices at concentrations of up to 10 Î¼M and hybrid male BDF1 mice at doses of up to 6 mg/kg with no obvious toxicity observed in either experiment.(90) The survival of BDF1 mice with L1210 leukemia was extended from 13.7 days to 17.5 days when prodrug 21 was administrated via iv six times daily at a low dose of 26 Î¼g/kg.(90) Prodrug 21 showed good antitumor potency and preferable safety profiles; however, high lipophilicity led to difficulties in administering prodrug 21 and potentially caused poor reproducibility of therapeutic effects in clinical trials. Consequently, prodrug 22 (Figure 10), where the N-benzyl fragment was replaced with N-propargyl, led to a decrease in lipophilicity compared to 21 (22, logÂ P = 3.78; 21, logÂ P = 4.51).(93) Prodrug 22 was markedly more water-soluble, resulting in a significant increase in its ROS-generation properties, which was approximately 7-fold more efficient than 21 in ROS generation in BL-2 cancer cells. Prodrug 22 was active toward a series of cancer cells with IC50 values ranging from 15 to 31 Î¼M, while it was found to be nontoxic toward normal cells up to 50 Î¼M.(93) Notably, 22 significantly inhibited Guerinâs carcinoma (T8) growth with in vivo dosing at 30 mg/kg.(93)
    Interestingly, prodrug 23 was designed by inserting two phenylboronate-type ROS-responsive triggers onto the aminoferrocene scaffold.(92) Prodrug 23 manifested increased cytotoxicity toward HL-60 cells with an IC50 of 12 Î¼M, which was more potent than the monoboronate prodrug 21 (IC50 = 52 Î¼M). This may be due to increased levels of the toxic p-QM, thus causing more robust suppression of the intracellular antioxidant system.(92) Considering that lysosomes contained a higher level of ROS and iron ions responsible for producing highly toxic HOÂ·, Mokhir et al. further designed ROS-responsive prodrug 24 with a piperidine moiety introduced onto the benzyl group to make it lysosome-specific targeting.(94) The piperidine moiety is predicted to be protonated in the acidic environment of lysosomes, facilitating prodrug 24 to be captured within lysosomes. Prodrug 24 was more sensitive to relatively higher levels of ROS in lysosomes and released the parent drug more efficiently than in the cytoplasm. It was found that 24 was 6- to 7-fold more cytotoxic than its counterpart 21 toward a variety of cancer cells, including BL-2, Jurkat, and DU-145 cancer cells, with IC50 values ranging between 3.5 and 7.2 Î¼M. Notably, 24 was shown to be weakly toxic against noncancer human dermal fibroblast adult (HDFa) cells (IC50 = 30 Î¼M). The murine NemethâKellner lymphoma model revealed that 24 significantly inhibited tumor growth in vivo at a dose of 40 mg/kg.(94)
    Platinum-based drugs such as carboplatin, cisplatin, and oxaliplatin have been successfully used clinically for the treatment of several cancers, including testicular cancer, ovarian cancer, and colorectal cancer.(95,96) However, it is challenging for platinum-based drugs to be selectively uptaken by cancer cells so that sufficient concentration for therapeutic effects can be achieved.(97) Clinical use of platinum-based drugs is significantly limited due to the dose-limiting and severe side effects.(98) Mokhir et al. reported a novel conjugate (25) of a clinically used platinum-based drug carboplatin with the ROS-responsive aminoferrocene moiety mentioned above which targets cancer cell mitochondria (Figure 11).(99) In the cancer microenvironment with elevated levels of ROS, the ROS-sensitive phenylboronate moiety in 25 could be cleaved to generate ferrocenium-based delocalized lipophilic cations (DLCs). Given that cancer cells showed a much more negative mitochondrial transmembrane potential than normal cells, the resultant carboplatin linked with DLCs could be taken up selectively by cancer cells.(99) It was found that 25 could deliver a 5.7-fold increased amount of platinum to the mitochondria of A2780 human ovarian cancer cells than the parent drug carboplatin. As a consequence, 25 manifested a significantly higher anticancer potency (IC50 = 35 Î¼M) than the parent drug carboplatin (IC50 > 200 Î¼M) toward A2780 cancer cells with a 24 h incubation. Notably, 25 was nontoxic toward normal human dermal fibroblasts (NHDF) cells, showing substantially higher anticancer activity and selectivity.(99) A similar ROS-responsive prodrug (26) based on cisplatin was reported by the Mokhir group, which contains two ROS-responsive aminoferrocene fragments (Figure 11).(100) Prodrug 26 was first activated due to high levels of ROS in tumor cells. The two aminoferrocene fragments behave as electronic donors, providing two electrons to rapidly and effectively attack an electronic receptor Pt(IV), thus releasing the parent drug cisplatin. Prodrug 26 showed potent inhibitory activity toward A2780 cancer cells and cisplatin-resistant A2780cis cancer cells with IC50 values of 2.5 and 6 Î¼M, respectively, while remaining nontoxic to HDFa normal cells (IC50 > 25 Î¼M).(100) In 2018, Mokhir et al. further reported a ROS-responsive prodrug (27) based on oxaliplatin with a similar release mechanism to that of 26.(101) Prodrug 27 was more potent than 26 toward both A2780 and A2780cis cancer cells with IC50 values of 0.4 and 0.7 Î¼M, respectively. Prodrug 27 showed a 45-fold reduced activity toward normal HDFa cells, suggesting that the ROS-responsive prodrug strategy should result in reducing the side effects of platinum-based chemotherapeutic drugs in cancer therapy.(101)
    In addition to the boronate moiety, selenium (Se), tellurium (Te), and sulfur atoms have been explored as ROS-responsive trigger groups. Carbon monoxide (CO) has been considered as a potential therapeutic agent for cancer therapy,(102) and its controlled release in cancer cells is of great importance. In 2017, Wang et al. reported a novel series of selenium-containing organic CO prodrugs, as represented by 28 and 29 (Figure 12),(49) where the phenylselenyl group acts as an effective ROS trigger group. The selenium group is prone to be oxidized by elevated levels of ROS in cancer cells, such as hypochlorite (ClOâ), singlet oxygen (1O2), and superoxide (O2â). The formed selenoxide analog then undergoes syn-elimination (selenoxide elimination) to form a double bond between the C5 and C6 site, ready for the subsequent cheletropic reaction to rapidly release CO under physiological conditions (as shown in Figure 4). It is worth noting that the phenylselenyl group is finally converted to a nontoxic byproduct, phenylselenenic acid, with an LD50 value of 1200 Î¼mol/kg in mice.(49) The selective release of CO by prodrug 29 in cancer cells resulted in a significant synergistic effect when combined with DOX, an anticancer drug. Treatment with 2 Î¼M DOX alone showed a 20% growth inhibition on HeLa cells, while DOX used in combination with prodrug 29 (12.5 Î¼M) resulted in a considerably raised inhibitory rate, up to 80%.(49)
    As Te shares similar chemical properties to that of Se, Xu et al. designed a Î³ radiation-responsive Te-containing side-chain polymer PEG-b-PAA-g-Te (30) for cancer therapy.(55) The currently used chemotherapeutic drug cisplatin is coordinated with the polymer, which then self-assembles in an aqueous solution with cisplatin in the hydrophobic core of the nanoparticles. As a consequence, the cytotoxicity of cisplatin is temporarily reduced in structure 30 due to the coordination effects, which reduces the side effects of the nanomedicine. Low doses of Î³ radiation cause the Te-containing moiety of the nanoparticles to be oxidized due to the enhanced ROS levels. Such oxidation leads to increased hydrophilicity of the nanoparticles and weakens the coordination between cisplatin and Te, facilitating the release of cisplatin from the nanoparticles and subsequent return of the cisplatin cytotoxicity. Also, Te in the nanoparticles increases the concentration of intracellular ROS to induce apoptosis in MDA-MB-231 cells. The synergistic mechanisms of chemotherapy and radiotherapy reduce both the required radiation and chemotherapy doses for treatment on the premise of ensuring the therapeutic effect.(55)
    Sun et al. designed a ROS-triggered prodrug (31), thioether-linked linoleic acidâpaclitaxel conjugate (PTX-S-LA), which was used in the design and preparation of self-strengthened bioactivating prodrug-based nanoparticles that consist of PTX-S-LA and Î²-lapachone (LAP).(54) In cancer cells, oxidation-responsive self-strengthened prodrug-based polymeric micelles (LAP/PTX-S-LA PMs) release LAP, which can elevate the cellular ROS levels. Consequently, LAP-induced ROS combined with endogenous ROS can contribute to the oxidization of the thioether bond, leading to the release of the active cytotoxic agent PTX. When the molar ratio of prodrug 31 to LAP in PMS is 1:3, the IC50 of PTX-S-LA PMs treated 4T1 and A549 cancer cells were 126.7 nM and 176.2 nM, respectively. Furthermore, the LAP/PTX-S-LA PMs showed similar cancer cell killing ability compared with paclitaxel (Taxol). In NIH 3T3 normal cells, the IC50 of PTX-S-LA PMs was similar to that of LAP/PTX-S-LA PMs, implying that LAP/PTX-S-LA PMs are less toxic for normal cells. Additionally, the AUC (area under the curve) of LAP/PTX-S-LA PMs was 11-fold that of PTX, indicating that LAP/PTX-S-LA PMs prolong systemic circulation and enhance tumor accumulation. LCP/PTX-S-LA-PMs exhibited better in vivo anticancer efficacy in 4T1 xenograft mice than PTX.(54)
    Melphalan (MPH), an alkylating anticancer agent, can be used for the treatment of glioblastoma (GBM), the most common and invasive primary brain tumor.(103) However, low water solubility (0.1 Î¼g/mL) and poor selectivity toward cancer cells of MPH result in limited clinical use.(104) In 2020, Duskey et al. reported a prodrug of MPH, mPEGTK-MPH (32), by introducing a ROS-responsive group thioketal (TK) together with water-soluble polyethylene glycol (PEG) (Figure 12).(52) It was found that 32 possessed both a hydrophilic portion (PEG) and a hydrophobic component (MPH), which results in self-association in aqueous solutions. Nanosized micelles of 32 could be selectively uptaken by GBM cells; the sulfur-containing TK linker is sensitive to the high levels of ROS in GBM cancer cells (Figure 4), leading to the cancer-cell-selective release of the cytotoxic parent drug MPH.(52)

    3.2. ROS-Responsive Anti-Inflammatory Prodrugs

    Oxidative stress has been considered as one of the specific features in the pathogenesis of inflammation.(105,106) Under pathological inflammatory conditions, the extracellular levels of H2O2 in the inflammatory site were found to be over 100 times more than in the healthy tissue, reaching a concentration as high as 1.0 mM.(107,108) Thus, high levels of H2O2 could be used as the stimulant for prodrug activation, making it reasonable for modifying anti-inflammatory drugs into ROS-responsive prodrugs. A variety of clinical anti-inflammatory agents have been modified into prodrugs by introducing ROS-responsive groups, such as thiazolidinone or arylboronate, resulting in reduced toxicity to normal cells, enhanced anti-inflammatory efficiency, and improved metabolic stability.(109â122)
    Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic systemic inflammatory disease that can cause severe joint injury and other extra-articular changes.(110) Low-dose methotrexate (LD-MTX, Figure 13) is the standard treatment for RA;(111) however, its clinical application is limited due to serious adverse effects, low efficacy, and pharmacokinetic inadequacies. Thus, more effective and safer therapies for RA are needed.(112,113) The carboxyl functional group of MTX (Figure 13) is a common prodrug modification target. Carboxylic acids can be esterified to improve pharmacokinetic profiles, but this strategy is not disease-targeting.(114,115) Clausen et al. suggested a thiazolidinone-based H2O2-responsive MTX prodrug 33 (Figure 13) for the selective delivery of MTX to inflammatory tissues, assuming that inflammation is related to elevated levels of ROS, such as H2O2.(47) Prodrug 33 was metabolically stable and water-soluble and could be activated by pathophysiological levels of ROS, reverting to MTX by converting the thiazolidinone moiety back to the carboxyl group.(47) In the collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mouse model, 33 manifested promising potency comparable to MTX and exhibited improved safety profiles. The mice treated with 33 experienced a more stable body weight as compared to the MTX-treated group.(47) Additionally, the Clausen group reported two more phenylboronate ROS-responsive prodrugs (34 and 35) (Figure 13) based on the MTX structure.(109,116) Both of these prodrugs showed acceptable chemical and metabolic stability in various physiological conditions of blood (pH = 7.4), under simulated gastric fluid (SGF) acidic conditions, under simulated intestinal fluid (SIF) basic conditions, and in liver microsomes.(109) Treated with equimolar doses of prodrug 34 (9.7 mg/kg) and 35 (8.8 mg/kg) once daily for 2 weeks in the CIA DBA/1J mice model, the incidence of arthritis was reduced, with a similar response to those treated with MTX (7.0 mg/kg). Notably, no obvious side effects were observed for the groups treated with 34 and 35, while the MTX-treated group showed a significant body-weight loss.(109) These results suggested that the ROS-responsive prodrug strategy, as exemplified by prodrugs 34 and 35, is useful for modifying anti-inflammatory agents to their corresponding prodrugs with sustained efficacy in controlling the development of arthritis disease and improved safety profiles. Interestingly, prodrugs 34 and 35 with phenylboronates as the ROS-trigger groups were found to be more effective in RA therapy than prodrug 33 using a thiazolidinone as the ROS-trigger moiety.(116)
    In the inflammatory response induced by ischemia, matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), a family of Zn(II) dependent hydrolytic enzymes, can be activated by ROS, resulting in the disruption of the bloodâbrain barrier (BBB), leading to cell death. Therefore, MMP inhibitors (MMPi) are considered to have therapeutic potential for treating neurological disorders, including stroke or neuroinflammation by ameliorating BBB dysfunction.(117,118) However, poor selectivity and dose-limiting side effects significantly hindered the clinical application of MMPi.(119) Cohen et al. reported the first ROS-responsive prodrug approach for MMPi, utilizing targets such as 1,2-HOPO-2 and PY-2 (Figure 14), by masking the key hydroxy group responsible for the zinc-binding with a phenylboronate moiety, generating the corresponding prodrugs, 36 and 37 (Figure 14).(120) Prodrugs 36 and 37 manifested poor inhibition against MMP-9 with IC50 values of >1 mM, representing a >100-fold increase compared with the parent active counterparts. Following exposure to a high concentration of H2O2 (100 Î¼M), the MMP-9 inhibition by prodrug 36 and 37 recovered to a level similar to the parent active inhibitor 1,2-HOPO-2 and PY-2. Interestingly, these prodrugs were thought to have a dual-action mechanism to prevent reperfusion injury by cleaving elevated ROS and generating a potent MMPi, inferring a potential to reduce the side effects of the BBB disruption caused by stroke.(120)
    The transcription factor nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2) regulates cellular oxidative stress by enhancing the antioxidant system.(121) The Kelch-like ECH-associated protein 1 (Keap1) is a negative regulator of Nrf2; thus, inhibitors of the Keak1-Nrf2 proteinâprotein interaction (PPI) could be developed as anti-inflammatory agents.(122) In 2020, Jiang et al. reported a new Keap1-Nrf2 inhibitor (Figure 14) with an IC50 of 96.7 nM. Subsequently, the carboxyl pharmacophoric moiety was masked using a ROS-responsive thiazolidinone group to generate the first ROS-responsive prodrug (36) (Figure 14) for Keap1-Nrf2 inhibition. Prodrug 37 remained inactive and was chemically and metabolically stable in various physiological conditions. When exposed to H2O2 or inflammatory cells, it efficiently converted into the carboxyl parent agent to activate the Nrf2 pathway. Additionally, prodrug 36 was more permeable to cross cell membranes (Pe = 6.35 Ã 10â6 cm/s) compared to the parent compound (Pe = 0.80 Ã 10â6 cm/s) and showed a significantly increased activity of Nrf induction with an EC50 of 0.32 Î¼M in lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-treated HepG2-ARE-C8 cells when compared to the parent compound (EC50 = 13.14 Î¼M).(122) Importantly, prodrug 36 showed preferable pharmacokinetic properties for oral administration with a bioavailability of 68.1%. LPS-induced inflammatory C57BL/6 mice model showed 36 to have significant anti-inflammatory effects comparable to dexamethasone orally dosed at 10 mg/kg, which was much more potent than its parent compound even at a higher dose (40 mg/kg).(122)
    Ischemiaâreperfusion (I/R) injury has been observed in various clinical conditions, such as acute coronary syndrome, hepatic and renal ischemic insults, cardiopulmonary bypass surgery, and vascular thromboembolic events.(123) ROS accumulation and oxidative damage have both been associated with I/R injury.(123) Therefore, H2O2 presents a strategic target for therapy directed at the site of I/R injury. Following the induction of intracellular oxidative stress by ROS, a large number of unfolded proteins accumulate in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) and induce an unfolded protein response (UPR). ATF6 is a key stress protein in UPR, and activation of ATF6 helps to regulate ER stress responses and maintain the activity of antioxidant enzymes by scavenging ROS.(123,124) Cooley et al. designed and synthesized an ATF6 activator prodrug (39).(124) In a simulated I/R injury model, the mediator level of lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) (a marker of cell necrosis) in the 39-treated group was approximately half of the control group, and prodrug 39 significantly improved the survival rate of myocardial tissue.(124) Kang et al. developed the H2O2-activatable I/R targeted prodrug (40).(125) On one hand, prodrug 40 uses the protective group, self-immolative boronic ester, to scavenge cellular H2O2. On the other hand, upon reaction with H2O2, it releases HBA (p-hydroxybenzyl alcohol) which inhibits the expression of the proinflammatory cytokine TNF-Î± (tumor necrosis factor Î±) and exerts potent antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities. Prodrug 40 showed a significant protective effect on hepatic and cardiac I/R injury at a dose of less than 5 mg/kg, while a dosage of at least 25 mg/kg was required for HBA to exert sufficient therapeutic effects. No obvious abnormalities in renal or hepatic function were observed in mice after administering prodrug 40 (1.5 (mg/kg)/day) daily for 7 continuous days. These results infer that prodrug 40 has significant therapeutic benefits in the treatment of I/R injury due to its low effective dose and high therapeutic activity.(125)

    4. ROS-Responsive Probes

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Small-molecule probe-based fluorescence imaging technology has become an indispensable method in the field of biology and medicine. To achieve ROS-specific imaging, probes based on arylboronates have attracted researchersâ interest due to their high specificity for the main ROS in cells, H2O2, under physiological conditions.(34,35) In 2004, Chang et al. first reported a new class of boronate-based fluorescent probes, represented by peroxyfluor-1 (41) (Figure 15), for intracellular imaging of H2O2 in living biological samples.(126) Compound 41 represents a 10- to 100-fold increase in H2O2 selectivity compared to previously reported probes. Subsequently, peroxyresorufin-1 (42) and peroxyxanthone-1 (43) were developed and they both also showed excellent selectivity for intracellular H2O2.(127) Using this strategy, the Chang group further developed peroxy green 1 (PO1) (44) and peroxy crimson 1 (PC1) (45) for visualizing endogenous H2O2 in living cells after growth factor stimulation, including the first direct imaging of H2O2 involvement in brain cell signaling. These probes facilitate a novel mechanism for exploring the rapidly expanding role of H2O2 in cellular signal transduction.(128) Boronate deprotection has become a general, chemoselective strategy for developing fluorescent probes with unprecedented selectivity for H2O2 relative to cellular ROS.
    To date, various ROS-responsive fluorescent probes have been developed specifically for targeting different subcellular organelles, such as mitochondria, lysosomes, and nuclei, as well as for pathological tissues. The ROS-responsive fluorescence probes allow visualization of the localized production and accumulation of intracellular H2O2 in cells or animals, which is potentially useful for the clinical diagnosis of ROS-related diseases, including cancer, inflammation, and neurodegenerative diseases such as AD and PD.(11â13)

    4.1. Subcellular Organelle-Targetable ROS Probes

    4.1.1. Mitochondrial-Targeting ROS Probes

    The mitochondrion, as the main site for cell respiration, is the primary source of ROS. H2O2, as the main ROS in the mitochondrion, is critical for cell survival, growth, and differentiation. Changes in cell levels of H2O2 are closely related to the development of various diseases, including cancer.(129,130) A variety of probes were designed and synthesized to monitor changes of endogenous H2O2 in mitochondria. The negatively charged mitochondrial membrane (â180 mV)(131) has been used for developing mitochondrial-targeting probes by introducing positively charged groups, such as triphenylphosphonium salt (TPP). In 2008, Chang et al. designed and synthesized a mitochondrial-targeting fluorescence probe (46) (Figure 16) for imaging H2O2. Prodrug 46 consisted of a dihydrorhodamine (DHR) moiety as the fluorescent reporter, an arylboronate moiety as the ROS-responsive group, and a positive-charged TPP moiety as the mitochondrial-targeting group.(132) Upon exposure to high levels of H2O2, probe 46 could stimulate considerably enhanced fluorescence emission (Î»em = 528 nm), enabling the visualization of endogenous H2O2 formation in the mitochondria of living cells. Notably, 46 was capable of detecting changes in the H2O2 elevations in a PD model with oxidative stress.(132) In 2012, Kim et al. developed a two-photon fluorescence probe 47 (Figure 15), with a TPP moiety as the mitochondrial-targeting group, a phenylboronate as the ROS-responsive group, and an aminonaphthenyl benzothiazole fragment as the reporter.(133) Probe 47 showed a remarkable emission color change from blue to yellow in response to H2O2, excellent selectivity to mitochondrial H2O2, good safety profiles, and good stability in a range of physiological conditions. One-photon fluorescence probes generally have limitations in deep tissue imaging due to their relatively shallow penetration depth (<80 Î¼m).(133) Notably, probe 47 as a two-photon fluorescence probe was more suitable for quantitative imaging of H2O2 in living tissues at an increased penetration depth of 100â180 Î¼m.(133)
    In 2016, Peng et al. reported a mitochondrial-targeting near-infrared (NIR) fluorescence probe (48) (Figure 16) for imaging H2O2 in living animals.(134) It employed a positive quaternary amine for mitochondria targeting and an arylboronate moiety for H2O2 sensing. Importantly, probe 48 was successfully applied for the first time for in vivo imaging H2O2 related to an autophagy process.(134) Similarly, in 2017, Tang et al. reported another mitochondrial-targeting NIR fluorescent probe (49) (Figure 16) for H2O2, where a positive methylpyridine was used as the mitochondrial-targeting group and a classic phenylboronate as the ROS-sensitive group.(135) Prodrug 49 showed a weak emission band at 539 nm; upon exposure to H2O2, a new emission band turned up at 669 nm along with the disappearance of the 539 nm band, resulting in the efficient detection and imaging of H2O2 in living A549 cells.(135) In 2018, Zhang et al. studied a new mitochondrial-targeting ratiometric fluorescent probe (50) (Figure 16) for imaging H2O2 in living cells,(136) in which a coumarin scaffold was used as the fluorescent reporter, a positive alkylated pyridine for mitochondrial-targeting, and phenylboronate as the H2O2 responsive group. The strong electron-withdrawing effect of the pyridine cation led to a remarkable intermolecular charge transfer (ICT) process. As a consequence, probe 50 itself showed an intense red fluorescence emission at 640 nm. Upon exposure to H2O2, the phenylboronate moiety was cleaved through a 1,6-elimination reaction to weaken the electron-withdrawing effect, resulting in a remarkable blue-shift emission of probe 50 from 640 to 535 nm. Probe 50 can be used for quantitative and selective detection of cellular H2O2.(136) In 2018, Song et al. reported a mitochondrial-targeting fluorescent probe (51) (Figure 16) for imaging H2O2 in living cells, with a similar mechanism based on the ICT process in prodrug 50, using a different fluorescent reporter.(137)
    Recently, in 2019, Zhao et al. reported a mitochondrial-targeting fluorescent probe (52) (Figure 16) for detecting H2O2 in living cancer cells with low background fluorescence, utilizing a double-quenching strategy.(138) As shown in Figure 16, the 4-dimethylaminoazobenzene-4â²-carboxylic acid (DABCYL) moiety in 52 acts as a fluorescence quencher, resulting in a significant decrease in the background fluorescence intensity for 52. Upon exposure to H2O2, the conversion of the ROS-responsive phenylboronate group to a hydroxy group rapidly triggers a 1,6-elimination reaction of the self-cleavable linker to release the DABCYL quencher moiety, leading to a rapid and efficient release of the rhodamine fluorophore to give a strong fluorescence (Figure 17). This so-called double-quenching strategy resulted in a fluorescence enhancement of over 50-fold. As a consequence, probe 52 was capable of sensitively determining the concentration of H2O2 in mitochondria of living cells with a detection limit of 0.025 Î¼M.(138)
    In 2020, Zhang et al. synthesized a mitochondrial-targeted fluorescent probe (53) (Figure 16) for the detection of ONOOâ.(139) Probe 53 exhibits rapid response (<1 min), high selectivity, and also high sensitivity (detection limit = 16 nM). The fluorescence intensity at 569 nm is linearly related to ONOOâ levels (0â10 Î¼M). Probe 53 has been successfully used to monitor the fluctuation of endogenous ONOOâ concentrations and to observe H2S-induced ONOOâ scavenging in HeLa cells.(139)

    4.1.2. Lysosomes-Targeting ROS Probes

    Lysosomes are acidic (pH 4.5â5.0), single membrane coated, sac-like organelles responsible for the recycling and degradation of cell components.(140) Lysosomal disruption caused by elevated ROS levels can result in a significant amount of peroxidized proteins and lipids to be accumulated in lysosomes and has been considered to be closely related to a number of diseases, including cancer and aging-associated neurodegenerative disorders.(140,141) Thus, it is of great importance to develop assays for monitoring and detecting the levels of ROS in lysosomes.
    Given that lysosomes are much more acidic compared to other subcellular organelles, an alkaline moiety, such as morpholine, has commonly been used as a lysosome-locating group to enable the accumulation of probes or drugs within lysosomes.(142) Yoon et al. reported a lysosome-targeting fluorescent probe (54) (Figure 18) for visualizing H2O2 in cells, which incorporated naphthalimide as the fluorescent reporter, a morpholine moiety for lysosome targeting, and a ROS-responsive and cleavable phenylboronate group (Figure 19). Probe 54 manifested a high selectivity and sensitivity toward H2O2 compared with other ROS and displayed good water solubility, enabling its use in living cells.(142) Probe 54 itself showed very weak red emission in HeLa cells; however, once the HeLa cells were incubated with H2O2 (100 mM), an increase of red emission (Î»em= 528 nm) was observed.(142) Similarly, employing morpholine as the lysosome-locating moiety, Zhao et al. developed a lysosome-targeting and pH-sensitive fluorescence probe (55) for effectively visualizing endogenous H2O2 in lysosomes, without external stimulations, in HeLa cells, while negligible signal interference was observed from the cytoplasm and other subcellular organelles.(143)
    In 2016, Zhao et al. developed a pH-switchable and ROS-responsive probe (56) (Figure 18) for imaging intracellular H2O2 in acidic lysosomes in living cells.(144) Probe 56 itself only exhibited a weak fluorescence signal in the presence of the attached boronate quenching group. Upon exposure to H2O2, the boronate group was removed rapidly by H2O2-mediated oxidation, triggering the considerable enhancement of fluorescence signals. At low pH, the protonated form manifested remarkably stronger fluorescence emission; however, the corresponding deprotonated form showed weak fluorescence response, thus proving a high selectivity of the probe toward acidic lysosomes in cells (Figure 20).(144)

    4.1.3. Nucleus-Targeting ROS Probes

    The nucleus contains the majority of the genetic material of the cell, such as DNA, where the ROS levels have a significant influence on nuclear functions and gene transcription. Elevated ROS concentrations in the nucleus have been revealed to be related to various diseases, including cancer. Modifications of DNA oxidized by excessive ROS have been proved to exist in cancer tissues.(145) Thus, it is of great importance to develop probes for ROS imaging and detection specifically in the nucleus, thus helping us to more deeply understand the relationships between different levels of ROS in the nucleus and related diseases. However, relatively few numbers of the nucleus-targeting fluorescent probes have been reported to date.
    Reported strategies for designing nucleus-targeting ROS probes rely on attaching a DAN-binding or a nucleus-locating moiety onto a ROS-responsive fluorescent probe. Zhang et al. first developed the ROS-responsive fluorescent probe 57 (Figure 21) with a so-called SNAP-Tag, which was capable of modifying biomolecules via a nucleophilic substitution mediated by a Cys residue.(146) Histone H2B, a small protein containing 126 amino acids, is full of positively charged amino acid side chains at a physiological pH, allowing it to selectively and strongly interact in the nucleus with DNA, which has many negatively charged phosphate groups.(147) In light of this, Zhang et al. further applied the SNAP-Tag to covalently link with the histone H2B protein, generating an H2B-labeled ROS-responsive fluorescent probe 58 (Figure 21) for nuclear localization.(146) Additionally, Yi et al. reported a nucleus-targeting fluorescent probe (59) (Figure 21) for the highly sensitive detection of nuclear H2O2.(148) Probe 59 consisted of an arylboronate fluorescent moiety for ROS-targeting and fluorescent lighting and a peptide with a sequence VQRKRQKLMP-NH2, derived from the transcript factor NF-ÎºB, for guiding nuclear localization of the probe.(148) Once localized in the nucleus and exposed to ROS, probe 59 could be selectively activated with the maximum emission wavelength of 551 nm, enabling the nucleus-targeting detection of ROS in living cells.(148)

    4.2. Cancer-Cell-Targetable Fluorescent Probes

    In 2010, Chang et al. reported a viable bioluminescent probe 60 (Figure 22) for detecting fluctuations in H2O2 levels produced in living animals and the endogenous H2O2 levels in prostate tumor models.(149) On the basis of the expectations of increased H2O2 levels in cancer cells, probe 60 is activated by selectively cleavage of the H2O2-sensitive boronic acid group to generate firefly luciferin. Firefly luciferin then reacts with firefly luciferase enzyme to produce a bioluminescent readout and a 612 nm emission, which enables deep tissue signal penetration with an optical readout.(149) In 2017, Liang et al. developed a bioluminescence turn-on probe 61 by modification of the luciferin moiety for the highly selective detection of ClOâin vitro and imaging of ClOâ in tumors of living mice.(150) ClOâ can oxidize benzoyl hydrazine to generate water-unstable dibenzoyl diimide, followed by hydrolyzation to generate luciferin which fluoresces following the catalysis with the luciferase enzyme. In vitro experiments showed that 61 could be used in a highly selective detection method of ClOâ levels within the range of 0â62.5 Î¼M, with a lower limit of detection of 0.705 Î¼M.(150)
    To achieve cancer-selective imaging for ROS, in 2019, Shin et al. reported a NIR fluorescence probe (62) based on a triple targeting strategy (Figure 22).(151) This strategy employed three typical features that are highly elevated in cancer cells as targets for improving the cancer specificity, namely, somatostatin receptors (SSTRs), lysosomal protease cathepsin B, and ROS. Structurally, the designed triple-targeting probe 62 consists of (a) octreotide that binds to SSTRs, (b) a phenylboronic acid that is responsive to H2O2, (c) a dipeptide fragment that is a substrate for cathepsin B, and (d) a NIR fluorescence reporter for imaging.(151) Probe 62 itself was considered to be considerably weakly fluorescent as the NIR reporter was masked by an ether linker. Upon approaching the cancer cells, 62 would first be sensed by the SSTRs (first target) on the cellular membrane and be transported into the cancer cells via receptor-associated endocytosis. Second, the phenylboronate group attached to the lysine moiety with a carbamate linker would be self-immolatively cleaved through a 1,6-elimination upon exposure to high levels of H2O2 (second target) in cancer cells. Finally, the resultant uncaged dipeptide moiety in the probe is removed due to catalysis by cathepsin B which is overexpressed in cancer cells (third target), leading to the release of the strong fluorescent NIR reporter for imaging. Probe 62 was reported as being successful for selective imaging of cancer cells, including HeLa and A549 cells, without any interference from normal cells.(151)

    4.3. ROS-Responsive Probes for the Detection of Inflammatory Cells

    Liu et al. reported a ROS-responsive fluorescent probe (63) using 9H-1,3-dichloro-7-hydroxy-9,9-dimethylacridine-2-one (DDAO) as the fluorescent reporter (Figure 23).(152) Probe 63 exhibited dual modes of NIR fluorescence turn-on and ratiometric detection upon exposure to H2O2, making it useful for imaging of endogenous H2O2 generated in the inflammatory regions of mice induced by LPS.(158) Probe 63 showed an orange fluorescence emission (Î»em = 620 nm), which upon exposure to H2O2 shifted to a dark color (fluorescence emission peak at Î»em = 660 nm), resulting in the fluorescent color change of orange to red (Figure 23). Thus probe 63 could be used to quantitatively detect tissue concentrations of H2O2 utilizing the ratio of F660/F620. Over the range of 1 mM and 100 mM, the fluorescence intensity has an excellent linear correlation (R2 = 0.998) with the concentration of H2O2.(152) These results suggested that probe 63 has great potential for efficient and selective determination of the levels of ROS related to inflammation both in vitro and in vivo.

    4.4. ROS-Responsive Probes for the Detection of Neurodegenerative Diseases

    As mentioned previously, neurodegenerative diseases, including AD and PD, have been shown to be related to oxidative stress caused by high levels of ROS. Thus, it is of significant importance to monitor the variation of H2O2 levels in the brains of patients with neurodegenerative diseases for both disease diagnosis and drug development. Substantial evidence suggested that the amyloid-Î² protein (AÎ²) in brain regions responsible for cognition and memory could be regarded as a biological mark of the earliest symptoms of AD.(153,154) In 2006, Ran et al. designed a ROS-responsive probe 64 (Figure 24), CRANAD-88, that can pass through the BBB, producing a three-level cascade that amplifies near-infrared fluorescence (NIRF) signals upon exposure to elevated H2O2 levels in AD brains.(155) Curcumin analogs (AÎ² binding moiety) and boronates (H2O2 responsive moiety) were linked by a carbamate group, where the electron-withdrawing effect of carbamate significantly shortened the excitation/emission wavelength of 64 (Ex = 580 nm, Em = 690 nm), making it invisible for the near-infrared imaging. Upon exposure to high levels of H2O2 in AD brain cells (first fluorescence amplification), the phenylboronate moiety and carbamate linker could be self-immolatively eliminated, leading to a significant shift in the excitation/emission spectrum (Ex = 630 nm, Em = 730 nm) with a 3-fold enhancement of the fluorescence intensity.(155) Subsequently, the resultant part of the probe could bind to AÎ²s (second fluorescence amplification), causing a further 4-fold enhancement of the fluorescence intensity and a red-shift to produce a âvisibleâ NIRF signal (third amplification). Probe 64 was used during NIRF imaging on a transgenic AD mice model and revealed evidence for elevated levels of H2O2 in the AD mouse brains compared to the normal age-matched wild type mice.(155) These results suggested that the ROS-responsive probe 64 can be employed to monitor the H2O2 changes in brains of AD mice and provide a critical biological tool for the development of AD drugs.
    Additionally, in 2019, Huang et al. reported a deep-red H2O2 fluorescent probe 65 for detecting H2O2 levels in the brains of the PD Drosophila model (Figure 25).(156) Probe 65 was composed of a pyrimidine-based fluorescent reporter and a ROS-responsive phenylboronate with an ether linker. Upon exposure to ROS, especially H2O2, the deep-red fluorescence emission could be newly formed at 640 nm mediated by an ICT effect. The confocal laser scanning fluorescence imaging revealed that when treated with probe 65, the PD Drosophila brain showed significantly higher fluorescence intensity than the wild-type Drosophila brain, indicating that probe 65 has great potential in the study of the relationship between H2O2 overexpression and PD development.(156)

    5. ROS-Responsive Theranostic Prodrugs

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Theranostic drugs, as the name suggests, is a combination of both âtherapyâ and âdiagnosisâ functionalities within a single compound. Theranostic prodrugs are an emerging and exciting prodrug strategy, capable of diagnosing early stage diseases while simultaneously delivering therapeutic drugs to the lesion site, monitoring the drug release kinetics, and visualizing the disease development stage. This one-step approach can then lead to accurate, effective, and rapid therapies for patients.(157) Currently, the theranostic prodrug strategy is mainly applied in the field of cancer detection and treatment so far, so studies have relied on the overexpression of specific enzymes, elevated ROS, and redox imbalance in cancers to trigger the activation of diagnostic and deliver therapeutic drugs.(157)
    In 2014, Kim et al. reported a ROS-responsive and mitochondrial-targeting anticancer theranostic prodrug 66 (Figure 26) capable of effective cancer treatment and precise diagnosis in vivo.(158) Structurally, theranostic prodrug 66 is composed of four functional groups, as illustrated in Figure 25. The first is a cancer-targeting moiety, biotin, which guides 66 to cancer tissues. The second is a mitochondrial-targeting fluorescent reporter, ethidium, which shows a weak fluorescent signal in physiological aqueous environments; however, upon interaction with double-stranded DNA or RNA, it becomes strongly fluorescent. The third is an inactive drug, 5â²-deoxy-5-fluorouridine (5â²-DFUR), which is converted into the active form, 5-fluorouracil (5-FU), upon the hydrolysis catalyzed by highly expressed thymidine phosphorylase in cancer cells. The fourth is a ROS-responsive phenylboronate moiety connected to a self-immolative linker. Upon exposure to elevated ROS in cancer tissues, the phenylboronate moiety is oxidized and hydrolyzed to release the parent antitumor drug 5â²-DFUR, followed by cleavage of the self-immolative linker to release the activated fluorescent reporter with a strong signal at 590 nm. In vitro cell-based assays revealed that 66 showed a significantly enhanced anticancer effect and a high selectivity toward cancer cells with overexpressed biotin receptors and elevated ROS levels, while no obvious cytotoxicity was observed toward normal cells. In vivo assays in a xenograft mouse model inoculated with human A549 lung cancer cells revealed that theranostic prodrug 66 could be selectively distributed in the tumor tissue, showing a fluorescence intensity approximately 7-fold higher than that of other normal tissues, including the lung, liver, heart, kidney, and spleen. Notably, 66 showed a significant inhibitory effect on tumor growth after an 8-weeks treatment in vivo.(158)
    Additionally, in 2014, Kim et al. reported a second ROS-responsive theranostic prodrug 67 for the selective treatment of metastatic cancers.(159) Prodrug 67 consists of three parts, a boronate moiety as a ROS trigger group, an effective anticancer drug, SN-38, which as a derivative of CPT, and a coumarin moiety that acts as both a self-cleavable linker and a fluorescent reporter for monitoring the release of SN-38 (Figure 27 and Figure 28).(159) Prodrug 67 can be activated by elevated H2O2 levels in cancer cells, resulting in the rapid release of the parent anticancer drug SN-38. The drug release process can be detected and monitored through the simultaneous release of the fluorophore with a strong fluorescence intensity at Î»max = 456 nm (Figure 28).(159) Prodrug 67 showed considerable cytotoxicity toward cancer cells, such as B16F10 and HeLa cells in the presence of H2O2, a condition mimetic for the tumor microenvironment with high levels of ROS, while it remained nontoxic toward cells under normal conditions. The metastatic lung tumor model induced by injection of B16F10 cancer cells revealed that theranostic prodrug 67, administrated at a low dose of 0.25 mg/kg, could be selectively distributed in metastasized lung tumor tissues, where it released the parent drug SN-38, showing an efficient and selective therapeutic activity in vivo.(159)
    In 2017, Toshima et al. reported a novel H2O2-responsive and photoactivatable theranostic prodrug 68 (Figure 27), targeting live cancer cells with elevated H2O2 levels.(160) Prodrug 68 consists of three different functional structures. The first is a pro-fluorophore moiety composed of the protected resorufin with low cytotoxicity and preferable water solubility. The second is a photoactivatable moiety (photosensitizer), anthracene (AC), which can degrade biological macromolecules such as DNA, protein, and oligosaccharides by generating ROS under UV light irradiation. The third is a ROS-responsive arylboronate moiety. Upon exposure to elevated ROS in cancer cells, the boronate moiety underwent an oxidation reaction with H2O2, followed by hydrolysis to give a phenol, then undergoes a 1,6-elimination-based linker cleavage that results in the release of the photosensitizer moiety and the resorufin-based fluorescent reporter. This sequence of activation steps resulted in a 9-fold enhancement in the emission of red fluorescence at 590 nm (Î»ex = 530 nm).(160) Further cell-based assays showed that 68 not only produced fluorescence selectively in cancer cells, including HeLa cells, B16F10 cells, and A431 cells, with high levels of H2O2 but also induced cytotoxicity within the tested cancer cells under light irradiation.(160)
    In 2017, Chakrapani et al. developed an H2O2-responsive theranostic prodrug 69 (Figure 27) using nitric oxide (NO) as the anticancer agent to which a coupled fluorescence signal can track the release of NO in living cells.(161) A coumarin moiety, the same one used in prodrug 67, was inserted to be both a self-cleavable linker and a fluorescent reporter for monitoring the release of NO in 69.(161)
    In 2020, Cao et al. reported a ROS-responsive theranostic prodrug 70 (Figure 29) that was capable of delivering the anticancer agent, CPT, to the lysosomal matrix specifically by introducing a folate moiety as the cancer-targeting unit, which enabled the cellular penetration of 70 via endocytosis mechanisms.(162) The drug release was monitored by fluorescence in real time, relying on the LHX-OH fluorophore formed by H2O2 stimulation.(162) Prodrug 70 showed excellent selectivity between KB cancer cells (folate receptor-positive) and WI38 normal cells (folate receptor-negative). When treated with 5 Î¼M prodrug 70, the cell viability of KB cells was 70%, while the cell viability of WI38 cells was close to 100%. This is in direct contrast to CPT which is toxic to both the KB cells and WI38 cells with cell viability less than 30% at 5 Î¼M.(162)
    Liu et al. designed a ROS-responsive and self-luminescing theranostic nanosystem POCl (71) (Figure 30) under the inspiration of an intraparticle relayed resonance energy transfer strategy.(53) Upon exposure to H2O2, bis[3,4,6-trichloro-2-(pentyloxycarbonyl)phenyl]oxalate (CPPO) in 71 gave rise to a high-energy intermediate, 1,2-dixetanedione. The cascade energy was then transferred to poly[(9,9â²-dioctyl-2,7-divinylenefluorenylene)-alt-2-methoxy-5-(2-ethylhexyloxy)-1,4-phenylene] (PFPV) and finally received by the photosensitizer tetraphenylporphyrin (TPP). As a result, tumor tissue was converted to a âlight onâ state by TPP, facilitating the fluorescence imaging of tumor tissues. Meanwhile, the generated 1O2 caused oxidative damage to cancer cells, exerting antitumor effects (Figure 30). In vitro assays revealed that 71 significantly inhibited the growth of HeLa cancer cells in the presence of PFPV and H2O2, whereas 71 itself was confirmed as nontoxic toward normal liver LO2 cells. In vivo antitumor evaluation of 71 in mice bearing subdermal HeLa xenografts revealed that the tumor weights in the POCL group were significantly reduced by 85% compared with the control group following a 3-week treatment.(53) This ROS-responsive nanosystem triggered by the enhanced ROS levels in the tumor microenvironment provides an inner light source to excite 1O2 generation from TPP for cancer imaging and treatment, breaking through the limitations on penetration depth experienced when exploring with an external light source.

    6. Perspectives

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Given that significant differences exist in ROS levels between the nonpathogenic and pathological tissues, an increasing number of ROS-responsive prodrugs, probes, and theranostic prodrugs have been developed for the targeting treatment and precise diagnosis of ROS-related diseases. Indeed, the ROS-responsive prodrug strategy has been successfully applied to modify drugs used in clinical settings, showing improved therapeutic potency together with reduced side effects. This has been achieved by increasing the accumulation of active drugs within disease tissues, reducing doses required, and selectively releasing the active drug in disease sites. Many challenges concerning the ROS-responsive prodrugs remain to be solved, resulting in few ROS-responsive prodrugs having entered into clinical trials or been approved to date. As discussed, the phenylboronate moiety is the most commonly used ROS-trigger group for designing ROS-responsive prodrugs, which is composed of a boronate as the ROS trigger and a self-cleavable linker, benzyl, for 1â6 elimination. On the one hand, the introduction of this kind of ROS-responsive group leads to a significant increase in lipophilicity compared to the parent drug. Further addition of a disease-targetable structural functionality, such as cancer-targetable or subcellular organelle-targetable moiety, results in compounds with increased molecular sizes that would no longer meet the requirements of an approved drug. The increased lipophilicity and enlarged molecular sizes and weights would make the prodrug non-drug-like, according to Lipinskiâs ârule of fiveâ concerning drug-likeness.(163,164) On the other hand, drug release is usually accompanied by the release of the cytotoxic quinone-like fragment, such as p-QM, from the cleavable linker.(84,88,92) As p-QM is cytotoxic, its co-delivery may contribute to synergistic effects in the case of anticancer drugs. However, when released as a byproduct of delivery, p-QM would be toxic to both targeted and normal tissues and cause potential side effects when this prodrug strategy was applied in therapeutic agents for the treatment of inflammation and neurodegenerative diseases.
